Rankings look like they may not be helpful in this case. Due to 1) no improvement in the Iranian assessed score over the last 3 years (4.1), and 2) the complete alteration of the scoring criteria due in the 2016-17 edition of the GCI.   From the report:
"To capture these developments, the World Economic Forum has embarked on a two-year process of reviewing and modernizing the index. While most of the factors that were believed to determine competitiveness 10 years ago are still believed to do so today, to remain at the cutting edge the GCI methodology needs to be brought up to date with new elements and improved measurements. By doing so, the updated GCI will provide policymakers, businesses, and civil society with a better assessment of countries’ economic performance." Numerous criteria have been added (see the website) and the net change may not favor Iran: Freedom of the Press, Gov't. On line Services, Shareholder governance, Wireless broadband subscriptions, female participation rates in the work etc.  There may be a political component as well...the new criteria may be used to create additional pressure on some countries.  The change in scores, based on the new criteria, may be a key factor.
http://reports.weforum.org/global-competitiveness-report-2015-2016/appendix-a-measurement-of-key-concepts-and-preliminary-index-structure/ Also: Iran had a 4.1 score last year, identical to the score 3 years ago; there does not seem to be much change in the actual scores from year to year.  At the same time, rankings are highly volatile: Iran's last 4 were 82, 66, 83, and 74.  Contributing factors may include the changing number of countries that are ranked each year: for example 3 yrs ago there were 148, last year only 140.

Slight change from my last forecast dated 17 March, reducing  (<50)from 5% to zero and increasing (61-75) from 70 to 75. In the longer run Iran is definitely going to improve, but the reluctance of western banks to support dollar transactions (for fear of attracting US sanctions has been a setback, even though John Kerry denied just the other day that the US was obstructing such deals). The Economist Intelligence Unit published a White Paper in February entitled "All that glitters - Assessing opportunities and risks in postsanctions Iran" which forecast that Iran's overall ranking for "Business Environment" would increase by only one or two positions in 2016-20 compared to 2011-2015. The most significant improvement is expected under the sub-head of "Market Opportunities", also in "Macroeconomic Environment", "Political Stability", "Infrastructure" and the "Labour Market". Other sub-heads show only slight improvement but the only sub-head where the ranking worsens is under "Taxes". It thus looks like Iran will move up a few ranks within the (61-75) bracket, but it's not very likely it will rise into the next one. Falling below seems very unlikely especially as few other countries in the same bracket are likely to have progressed much during the global slowdown of the last year.

I calculated transition frequencies based on the GCI data: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B9XMTgf2QMKfU2g0S2NIeFpqTVU 23 greater than 14-place transitions out of 1210 YoY transitions gives base rate of ~1.8% for a rank below 61.
1 greater than 24-place transition gives base rate of  0.08% for below 51.
And a 38% base rate for a >1 drop back to a higher ranker! I think Iran's ranking could also decrease, given this: http://www.tradingeconomics.com/iran/competitiveness-rank/forecast. If its score stays about the same but others improve then it could fall out of the top 75. But another way to think about this: On average, in any given YoY transition, 0.1 country will move up at least 25 rankings. Of the 151 countries, is Iran overweight in the probability distribution of being amongst them? Ie should we adjust the base rate up? To get to a probability that even rounds up to 1%, we must believe that Iran is 7 times more likely than average to be the country that experiences this level of jump (which only happens to one country every 9 years). That doesn't sound crazy, they're in a pretty special situation, given that the surveys were done earlier in the year I'm still a bit nervous. To put it another way, what are the chances that Iran are not only the most-improving country, but that their rank improves in a way that the most-improving sees only about once every 10 years. I think below 0.5%. On average, in any given YoY transition, 2.5 countries will move up at least 15 rankings. Of the 151 countries, is Iran overweight in the probability distribution of being amongst them?
Or in other words, what do we think are Iran's chances of being in the top 2.5 highest-improving countries? Again, I think things are somewhat limited by the early date of the survey, but I think it's fair to say they have a 5x as likely chance of being one of these big movers than usual, or if we assume uniform likelihood across top 25 position making for a 8.5% probability of moving up to 60 or better. On average, every year 57 countries will move down by at least 2 ranks. What are the chances Iran is in the bottom 57 countries in terms of YoY change? I think this is only 25% as likely as the "usual" case, so .25 * .38 = 9.5%.

Feb  21: "THE PERSIAN RUG TRADE IS BACK IN BUSINESS" --> http://www.newsweek.com/persian-rugs-iran-sanctions-428789 Sanctions on Iran were all about oil, right? Yes, but a little-known fact is that the international sanctions imposed over the past decade to curb Iran’s nuclear ambitions had a devastating effect on its second largest export: the iconic Persian rug. Until January, when President Barack Obama signed an executive order lifting sanctions, all Persian rugs—whether antique or brand-new—were banned from entering the U.S., regardless of how long they had been outside Iran. For instance, a Persian rug sold in London that had not been in Iran for more than a century still could not be shipped to the United States.
[...]
It’s not just the antique Persian rug business that’s taken a hit. Sanctions also eroded the modern rug trade in Iran, according to Hamid Kargar, head of Iran’s National Carpet Center in Tehran. Revenue from all Persian rug exports has fallen from around a billion dollars a year in 2000, the last time sanctions were lifted, to just over $300 million a year today, he tells Newsweek. By 2010, just before the latest round of sanctions were reinstated, Persian rug exports to the U.S. came to around $80 million a year, or 16 percent of Iran’s total shipments.
[...]
Unfortunately for the Iranian rug industry, while the U.S. and Iran were engaged in their lengthy standoff, the world moved on to more modern floor coverings. “Millennials are not buying traditional; they’re looking for urban contemporary,” says Richard Amatulli, membership chairman of the Oriental Rug Retailers of America, a nonprofit trade group based in Landrum, South Carolina. “Also, what’s coming out of Iran is new stuff. All the old stuff, all the great stuff, they already got out. And the new stuff doesn’t have a market yet.” On top of the sanctions, the Great Recession of 2008–2009 killed the price of Persian rugs, says Amatulli. “It’s been devastating to the industry,” he says. “I’ve seen some rugs priced at just one-tenth of what they’d been worth after the first round of sanctions in the 1980s.”

H/T to the series of forecasts from @einsteinjs but reaching different conclusions.  Just to summarize last year's index for Iran in the 12 pillars 1. Institutions - Iran was 94th
2. Infrastructure - 63rd
3. Macroeconomic Environment - 66th
4. Health and Primary Education - 47th
5. Higher Education and Training -69th
6. Goods Market Efficiency - 69th
7. Labor Market Efficiency - 138th
8. Financial Market Development - 134th
9. Technological Readiness - 99th
10. Market Size - 19th
11. Business Sophistication - 110th
12. Innovation - 90th The pillars where Iran is ranked lowest and thus has the most potential to improve are, in reverse order
Labor Market Efficiency (138), Financial Market Development (134), Business Sophistication (110), Technological Readiness (99) and Institutions (94). Since the Rouhani government is primarily responsible for the economy, it could improve pillars such as Financial Market Development and Technological Readiness with relaxation of nuclear-related sanctions.  However, there are only a few months left before the next Index is compiled and it seems unlikely there could be a major improvement in any one pillar, or in the overall index in the time available. There should be an improvement in relative rankings, not only because of the nuclear deal but also because due to sanctions restricting its exports, Iran will be less hurt by low oil prices than other oil exporters. A victory - currently not expected by most observers - for Rouhani's supporters in the upcoming elections could also help. It should be noted that only two pillars (Market Size at #19 and Health and Primary Education, at #47) were in the top 50 last year with none between 51 and 60. On that basis I've been ruling out Iran reaching the top 50 this year.  Similarly, while I'm confident Iran will improve its ranking, I'm less certain about it entering the top 60. The pillars currently in the 61-75 range are Infrastructure (63), Macroeconomic Environment (66), Higher Education and Training (69) and Goods Market Efficiency (69). Macroeconomic Environment in particular could improve but the others may not in the time available. The above rankings have been taken from http://www.irna.ir/en/News/81783312/. As noted there, Iran climbed 9 places in the Index last year despite sanctions, so one can expect it to continue its rise after some of those restrictions have been lifted. The only question is by how much it will improve.

Feb 1: "Sanctions Made Iran Resilient to Low Oil Price, Moody's Says" --> http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-02-01/iran-gdp-poised-to-grow-in-aftermath-of-sanctions-moody-s-says In an ironic twist, international sanctions against Iran appear to be benefiting its economy as decades of isolation forced the nation to adapt to low oil prices more quickly than other crude exporters, according to Moody’s Investors Service. Gross domestic product will grow 5 percent in 2016-2017, thanks to a solid foundation built to cope with exclusion from the global financial system, Moody’s said in an e-mailed research note Monday. Removal of sanctions as part of a nuclear deal reached last year will grant Iran access to about $150 billion in its frozen foreign assets, which will be spent on reviving the country’s aging infrastructure, it said. The country also will regain access to the international payment system, lowering trade and financial costs. “International sanctions meant that Iran had to adapt to the reality of lower oil revenues and implement structural reforms much earlier than other oil-exporters,” Atsi Sheth, an associate managing director at Moody’s, said in a statement. “Most other oil-dependent sovereigns are only just beginning to consider structural fiscal reform.” Intensification of sanctions in 2012 forced Iran to remove exemptions for some large non-taxpayers and curb fuel subsidies to bring prices closer to market levels. “Since 2013, a combination of prudent policies, including increasing sources of non-oil revenues to pay for higher capital expenditures, combined with partial sanctions relief following the interim nuclear agreement led to a recovery, with real GDP growth at 4.3% in 2014,” Moody’s said in the report. Iran won’t suffer from capital flow volatility amid U.S. interest-rate increases because it has had minimal exposure to external debt and foreign direct investment, Moody’s said. With its $417 billion economy, which is the second-largest in the Middle East after Saudi Arabia and more diversified than other regional oil exporters, Iran has a solid foundation for rapid economic development and growth, Moody’s said. It also benefits from a young, well-educated labor force and a large industrial base, it said. ~~~ COMMENT: So... good (?) news for Iran? Hard to say. The thing that caught my eye was that I found the Bloomberg piece from a Fareed Zakaria OpEd (https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/from-iran-to-nigeria-cheap-oil-means-perilous-politics/2016/02/04/aefcdbb8-cb76-11e5-a7b2-5a2f824b02c9_story.html), which got me thinking about other petrol-dependent economies in the Middle East (and globally). That is, those economies for which oil is important on the supply side (or the demand side). So while Iran may not shoot up the rankings (for a number of reasons), it's possible that the countries around them descend on terribly low oil prices and because Iran's economy was already ready for it, they turn out to be a net positive.

This questions depends a great deal on whether or not the increase in economic investments resulting from the lifting of nuclear sanctions will be reflected in this report or not until next year's report. The report is released in Sept and I contacted WEF to ask if the report was a forecast or an assessment of real time data. Here's their reply: "The Global Competitiveness Report assesses the current state of competitiveness of a country. It is based on hard data and on data from our Executive Opinion Survey. Should you want to know more about the Executive Opinion Survey, please see p. 75 of the report (http://www3.weforum.org/docs/gcr/2015-2016/Global_Competitiveness_Report_2015-2016.pdf )." Interestingly, the survey is conducted in 41 languages but Farsi is not one of them. As far as the nuclear deal implications, it seems to me that a report released in Sept based on surveys will take time to complete and teh surveys are probably going to end by late summer at latest. So I'm inclined to think much of the nuclear deal's outcomes will not be felt in GCI rankings until next year's report.

<50 -- Upping form 22% to 23%
(51-60) -- Upping from 43% to 44%
(61-75) --  Lowering from 35% to 33% Jan 28: "Rouhani Goes Shopping in Europe as Iran Enjoys New Economic Freedoms" --> http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/29/world/europe/iran-hassan-rouhani-france.html Mr. Rouhani represents one-stop shopping by himself: The Iranian government controls 80 percent of the country’s economy. And with Iran’s population of around 80 million, much of it young and eager to spend after years of cheap Chinese goods, Western companies cannot get there fast enough. Deals and potential deals, signed and promised — for cars, planes, metals, pharmaceuticals — have been cascading. French companies should “rush” to Iran and “not waste any time,” said Pierre Gattaz, the president of the French employer federation Medef. ~~~ COMMENT: Alrighty, it's time to revisit my post from a few weeks ago (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/95594) where I looked at each of the pillars and places where Iran might up their score. In the NYT article above, cars, planes, metals, and pharmaceuticals were named. Mapping that onto the pillars: cars, planes, metal (2nd pillar -- INFRASTRUCTURE); pharmaceuticals (4th pillar -- HEALTH AND EDUCATION). [NOTE: I'm going to freely cite from the forecast I mentioned above.] Let's start with the easy one -- pharmaceuticals. Iran was already very strong on this pillar (6.0/7.0) and the only room for improvement I could see was in the primary education system. So, I don't think the news of pharmaceutical deals should have too much of an impact. Next: cars, planes, and metals -- infrastructure. Iran was hovering around the middle (4.2/7.0; second/third quartile) for this pillar, so it's possible that there may be some room for growth with deals like the ones announced. Of particular note in my initial assessment, "I would say the 'available airline seat kms' might be a place for growth." Hmmm, a deal with Airbus will certainly help with that. Of course, the deals won't suddenly mean Iran has 50 more Airbus's tomorrow, but depending upon how the raters view this, it could mean that this bumps up their score on "Transport Infrastructure," which would then bump up their score on the Infrastructure pillar, which would THEN up their score on the "basic requirements" subindex.  Given that I'm predicting that Iran is going to move to "Stage 2," this means that the allocation of % to 'basic requirements' is 60% (and there are only 4 'basic requirements' pillars), this could mean more of an overall uptick for Iran. It might be worth noting that of subindexes, 'basic requirements' was Iran's best (second/third quartile), so this uptick might not mean too much, but it's certainly something to keep in mind. Hastily Early ASSESSMENT: PUSH ~~~ SUMMARY of the hastily early assessments by subindex: Basic requirements:
PUSH: 4 Efficiency enhancers:
PUSH: 2 (with 1 to revisit)
Slightly UP: 3
Big UP: 1 Innovation/Sophistication:
PUSH: 1
Slightly UP: 1 ~~~ I debated whether to talk about this first or last, and I think it makes the most sense to talk about it at the end. It has to do with how WEF views each country's "stage of development." On page 38 of the 15/16 report (http://www3.weforum.org/docs/gcr/2015-2016/Global_Competitiveness_Report_2015-2016.pdf), check for the 
"Subindex weights and income thresholds for stages of development." [If you'd rather not look at the PDF, you can see it on this FAQ page, too --> http://reports.weforum.org/global-competitiveness-report-2015-2016/faqs/ (click on what is the weight scheme...)] This is important because depending upon a country's standing here, there will be different weights placed on the three subindexes (basic requirements, efficiency enhancers, and innovation and sophistication factors). How are these sorted -- GDP per capita. (Note: here's a link to Iran's GDP per capita --> http://www.tradingeconomics.com/iran/gdp-per-capita) In the 2015/2016 report, Iran's GDP per capita put them into the "transition from Stage 1 to Stage 2." And based on their previous GDP's per capita, it looks like they were in that same stage for the 2014/2015 report. The important thing to not here -- I'm fairly sure (80%) that Iran will now move into a new stage for the 2016/2017 report. Backing up for a moment, the stage they've been at (transition from 1 to 2) has a threshold of 2,000 to 2,999. Iran's GDP the last two years have been approximately 2950 (both years). Based on what I talked about in Part 1 (LINK TO PART 1 HERE), I suspect that Iran will bust through that 2,999-ceiling and move into Stage 2. Now, here are the weights for the two different stages: Transition from 1 to 2:
Basic requirements -- 40% to 60%
Efficiency enhancers -- 35% to 50%
innovation and sophistication -- 5 to 10% Stage 2:
Basic requirements -- 40%
Efficiency enhancers -- 50%
innovation and sophistication -- 10% ~ So, let's look at Iran's scores on the different subindexes. Basic requirements: 4.6 (second/third quartile)
Efficiency enhancers: 3.8 (third quartile)
Innovation and sophistication: 3.3 (third/fourth quartile) Using these scores and my "hastily early assessments," it appears that Iran can make some headway on the efficiency enhancers (3 slightly up's, 1 big up, and 1 to revisit for a possible slightly up). Let's say Iran is able to raise its total efficiency score by 10% (from 3.8 to 4.2), assuming that everything else with Iran stays the same AND every other country stays the same, that would raise Iran's ranking to 62. Let's say it's also able to get a 3% bump on innovation/sophistication -- that would push them into the top 60. Let's say Iran has a 20% bump in its efficiency enhancers score (and all else is equal) -- that would almost put it into the top 40!! At this point in the forecast, there are so many moving parts, so trying to account for it all (without the aid of a statistical program) is ludicrous. If I had to guess where Iran's "score" might land in the next report, I'd expect that they're guarantee to move up to the 4.1 (they came in at 4.09 last year) and are probably a good bet to finish above 4.2. Whether they can push into the 4.3's (or 4.4's!), I don't know. For now, this is where my reporting/analysis will pause. I certainly welcome other folks chiming in on this to make our understanding of these matters that much better.

Looking back historically, Iran ranked 69th on the Global Competitiveness Index in 2010 before the  Comprehensive Iran Sanctions, Accountability, and Divestment Act (CISADA) of 2010.  CISADA is a law passed by the U.S. Congress that further extended sanctions placed on the government of Iran under the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996.  Given that Iran ranked 69th in 2010, it stands to reason that even if sanctions are lifted Iran will not likely rise in the rankings from where it is now. Further, significant upward movement in the rankings short term is even more unlikely given the availability of oil, and depressed price of oil, which is expected to remain low for the next 18 months.  The wildcard in this calculus is the recent political unrest between Iran & Saudi Arabia which is spilling over to other states in the region bringing even more political and economic instability to Iran.  These are indeed uncharted waters.

As to whether it crosses below the 75th rank threshold, the average rank change for countries between 64 and 83 (a 20-rank range centered on 74; my way of approximating change in this section of the rankings) was 1.2 this year, 2 last year, and zero the year before that, so my prior is to assume a small positive change. Given that 5 of the 20 nations in the 64-83 range this year saw their ranking fall, as did 6 of 20 the year before, the average chance of dropping in rankings for a nation in this range is about 27.5%.

Hugely helpful in understanding the question: http://reports.weforum.org/global-competitiveness-report-2014-2015/methodology/ Basically the GCI is divided into 12 pillars of competitiveness but the performance in those categories affects countries in different stages of development in different ways. Iran's situation is summed up here on page 222: http://www3.weforum.org/docs/gcr/2015-2016/Global_Competitiveness_Report_2015-2016.pdf It is classified as a country in transition between factor-driven and efficiency-driven, closing in on efficiency driven status. This means that the weights attributed to the 12 pillars of competitiveness will approach this breakdown:
Basic requirements 40% (currently 40.9%)
Efficiency enhancers 50% (currently 49.4%)
Innovation and sophistication factors 10% (currently 9.8%)
In the last report Iran ranked 74 with rank 63, 90 and 102 in basics, efficiency and innovation respectively.  The most pressing issues for the country's economy are difficult access to financing, a high level of inflation, high unemployment, too much government bueraucracy and mismanagement, insufficient infrastructure. Iran's government apears dedicated to getting the sanctions lifted, I think it's highly unlikely they'll cheat. Khamenei has given the negotiators a strong mandate and people are expecting change. In the coming report we could see some progress in the sections-'pillars': macroeconomy (inflation dropping from 15 to 10%, better credit rating), goods market efficiency (additional foreign competition), financial market development (lifting sanctions on banks would be a huge deal), technological readiness (oil and gas tech).
I don't see how decisive improvements in the labour market, infrastructure, health, education and innovation could occour. Iran was 83rd in 2014-15 and now progressed to 74th in 2015-16... the same trajectory would take it to  something like 65th... in the next year.  Iran was ranked 66th prior to sanctions in 2012.  A position in the 60s would appear quite likely now that sanctions have been partly lifted.  In general terms, there are not many moves in this ranking of more than 10 places in any single year. Last year, the biggest moves were Cote D'Ivoire with a c.25 place improvement and El Salvador with an 11 place worse ranking than the year before. The vast majority of moves are less than 5 places from the previous year. Economic profiles in the end move slowly, particularly as these are relative to other countries rather than absolute. Worth noting that one of the pillars to this assessment is labour market efficiency. Iran ranks pretty much the worst on the planet here (139th) because of the effective exclusion of women. The country also ranks poorly on general levels of education etc. These type of measures are unlikely to improve just because sanctions are lifted. A move of more than 10 places is hard to justify. That said, a move just one place worse would see them in the >75 category... But it is reasonable to think that the lifting of sanctions will provide a greater boost than any other country in the 50-100 bucket will experience, suggesting that Iran will most likely improve relative to others. On this basis, a weaker ranking is a low probability event given the overwhelming likely impact of the lifting of sanctions.

Putting more in the bottom bucket on reflection - low oil, potential for mischief from hard-liners (eg. detention of business people can't be good), election unknowns, recent ranking in the 80's (2013, 2014).

Based on the data in the 6 years since 2011-2012, Iran has gotten an average rank of 73, with a standard deviation of 8.5.  If that describes Iran's rank this year, then the distribution should be <50: 0.4%, 51-60: 7%, 61-75: 54%, 75+: 39%.  This is a reasonable "base rate" estimate for this question.  The two big problems are:
a) this sort of estimate almost certainly underestimates the chance of an extreme rank, so <50 and 51-60 should be larger
b) The nuclear deal should be expected to push the average lower (because Iran becomes more competitive). To deal with these problems, I decided to
a) increase the standard deviation by 1.5
b) decrease the average by 10 (to 63, which is close to Iran's best ever rank)

	- To fit into top 50, Iran must rank up by 24, next bin requires improvement by 14 positions.
	- There has been only one jump of 24+ positions in WEF dataset - Côte d'Ivoire improved its position to 91 from 115 in 2015. 
	- 23 occasions in dataset where country has improved by 14+ positions.
	- There is no obvious pattern behind jumps, some of large improvements come after big drop, some enjoy high growth several years in a row. 
	- No country has jumped into top-35, but there has been several big movements in/near top-50, e.g. Portugal 51>36 (2014), Kazakhstan 72>51 (2012), India 71>55 (2015). Top 50 seems highly unlikely. 5%
